metadata.case_name: Akalu Ahir & Ors. v. Ramdeo Ram

facts.text: Three appellants (Akalu Ahir, Chandrika Singh, Jagarnath) and Ramchander Kanu tried before 2nd Assistant Sessions Judge, Chopra for offences under ss. 307 and 307/109 IPC.
Akalu Ahir and Chandrika Singh charged under s. 307 IPC for firing pistol shots and gun shots at Ramdeo Ram at 11.00 p.m. on June 13, 1966.
Jagarnath and Ramchander Kanu charged under ss. 307/109 IPC for abetting the offence.
Occurrence arose from election rivalry for office of Mukhia of village Arakpur; long-standing enmity between rival groups, providing motive for offence or false implication.
Three eye-witnesses: Ramdeo Ram (PW1, victim), Puljharia (PW9), Bhuidhar Chamar (PW10, ploughman).
Trial Judge acquitted accused, finding no doubt Ramdeo Ram injured by gun shots but not impressed by prosecution evidence on manner of occurrence; charges not proved beyond reasonable doubt.
State did not file appeal against acquittal.
Ramdeo Ram filed revision petition in Patna High Court in January 1969 under ss. 435 and 439 CrPC against acquittal of four accused.
Name of Jagarnath Kanu expunged from array of respondents in revision by court order dated July 3, 1969.

Patna High Court on October 14, 1969 allowed revision, set aside acquittal, ordered re-trial, finding trial court's appraisal of evidence infirm, misreading of PW1 evidence, immaterial contradictions.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court by three appellants.

legal_issues.text: Whether High Court can interfere in revision petition by private party against acquittal order and direct re-trial by re-appraising evidence.
Limits of High Court's revisional jurisdiction under ss. 435/439 CrPC against acquittal when State has not appealed.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court over-stepped limits of power in dealing with revisions against acquittals at instance of private parties.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: ss. 435, 439 CrPC; precedents like K.C. Reddy

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court not justified in examining evidence as court of appeal; required to check if trial court correctly appraised evidence.
Order directing re-trial uncalled for and would result in grave injustice.

respondent_arguments.text: No explicit arguments detailed; revision based on infirmities in trial court's evidence appraisal.

court_reasoning.text: Revisional jurisdiction under ss. 435/439 CrPC is extraordinary, discretionary, to correct grave injustices; not for re-appraising facts unless glaring legal defect causing failure of justice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court cannot act as appeal court; no conversion of acquittal to conviction directly or indirectly via re-trial.

court_reasoning.text: Private party has limited right in revision against acquittal; only in exceptional cases like jurisdictional error, shutting out evidence, overlooking material evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court re-weighed evidence contrary to precedents; trial court's appraisal not perfect but insufficient for interference.

court_reasoning.text: Re-trial exposes accused to harassment; not to be ordered lightly without procedural infirmity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court's opinion on evidence may unconsciously influence re-trial court.

holdings.text: High Court commits error in directing re-trial based on re-assessment of oral evidence in revision by private complainant.
Revisional power not to be exercised to convert acquittal into conviction indirectly; only in exceptional cases of glaring defects.

precedents_cited.relevance: Limits on High Court's interference in revision against acquittal.
High Court cannot convert acquittal to conviction even indirectly by re-trial.

precedents_cited.case_name: K. C. Reddy v. State of Andhra Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Categories of exceptional cases for interference in revision against acquittal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohendra Pratap Singh v. Sarju Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court not to re-weigh evidence in revision against acquittal.

precedents_cited.case_name: U.J.S. Chopra v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Historical background of appeal/revision against acquittal.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amar Chand Aggarwal v. Shanti Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Revisional jurisdiction exercised only in exceptional cases of glaring defect or manifest error.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences charged: attempt to murder and abetment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Revisional and appellate powers against acquittal; limits on private party interference.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, quashed the Patna High Court's order directing re-trial, and restored the trial court's order of acquittal.

key_quotes.text: Enmity as usual is a double-edged weapon, providing motive both for the offence as well as for false implication.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Caution in evaluating evidence in enmity cases.

key_quotes.text: The High Court when approached by a private party for exercising its power of revision from an order of acquittal, should appropriately refrain from interfering except when there is a glaring legal defect of a serious nature which has resulted in grave failure, of justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Trials are not to be lightly set aside when such orders expose the accused persons to a fresh trial with all its consequential harassment.
key_quotes.speaker: court
